pros: Love working here, would highly recommend it
cons: nothing comes to mind, love it

job_title: Worked In IT in McKinney, TX
pros: Benefits and vacations are good.
cons: Collin College, in general, is a hostile environment, especially the IT Programming Team, which has Programmers, DBA, and Application Admins. Management lacks managerial or organizational skills and micromanages. Management keeps the team in the dark with zero communication, but when there is communication, it is micromanaging, abusive and unprofessional. Management has harassed, bullied, and micromanaged many teammates off the team and out of Collin. Many managers here at Collin exemplify everything that a manager should not be. HR was looped in to help with the harassment and micromanagement from management, but the CIO chose not to act. Unfortunately, there is no hope as IT is under a new weak CIO. Some staff who have been at Collin for 20-plus years are also very rude and obnoxious. But their unprofessional behaviors are accepted as the norm. There is no collaboration within the team or departments. Additionally, Collin has no remote/hybrid options.

review_title: Great benefits but pay is lagging
job_title: Financial Aid Specialist in Plano, TX
pros: Health benefits are paid by the employer for the employee only. No cost to the employee. Also plenty of holidays off. Great work life balance. Also great education benefits.
cons: Busy during peak registration semesters. Kind of low pay avgs about $18 an hour as of now.

job_title: Professor of Music in Plano, TX
pros: Excellent colleagues - here, and there. Wonderful facilities. Very affordable tuition, so price is never a determining imposition for students! Furthermore, although it was a lot a large amount, I was afforded my own scholarship money to award every semester to the exceptional students of my choice. Undoubtedly, the greatest perk is the enormous budget available to the faculty, and students. I had a brand new beautiful office. Collin is an all Steinway institution. There is a large student body, which includes a pool of gifted students. Excellent schedule flexibility, excellent summer salary incentive, pension, sick pool, great [although gravely overworked) administrative assistants in the division offices, excellent faculty development support with generous travel budget. Price was simply NEVER an issue. (I had one $$ issue in all my years. In reality, it was just an ugly surprise, compliments of a vindictive dean.) The students are given a daily food stipend when traveling. Furthermore, we flew to our annual competitions, and stayed in the best hotels available. I was always afforded a private hotel room. (Wonderful!) .We rented an SUV upon arrival. Travel was always first class for the students, and faculty, which is truly a joy. The students never had to worry about the cost of travel. Nor did they have or try to save money that they didn’t have in order to participate. It was always free for all! Additionally, there is a completely separate financial resource available to the students through the student activities fund. Every student pays a $100 activity fee per semester into the activity fund. Quickly do the math. (53,000 students X $100 = $5,300,000) pouring into the student activity fund every semester! WOW! All for the asking. That’s incredible. Although the music department was under funded, I had a generous music literature budget each semester. It only took a few years to fill my file cabinet’s with the finest score’s available. Every piece I desired was at my fingertips. If I didn’t have it, I telephoned our music source, and charged my open PO. In retrospect, I never concerned myself with going over budget. The division secretaries, transferred more money into the PO, as needed. Although I had to share a studio space for applied lessons, it worked out well enough. Our studio was nice, although one never saw the sun on those days when lessons ruled the roost. The students, and I were afforded an incredible collaborative pianist in every lesson. She additionally went with me to every class. And, she traveled to competitions, etc. During my tenure, I designed, and taught 25 courses. ( Nice variety.) I had complete academic freedom, although I sometimes had to fight for it. Collin has an excellent curriculum advisory board. They are willing to accommodate the faculty with the approval of new, inventive, quality courses. I was fortunate over several years to have the opportunity to build my program. In doing so, I created the need for a full-time professorship. Voila! (That was not easy, mind you. And, doesn’t happen often.) Because I was the only full-time voice professor, I auditioned each incoming voice student, and placed them in the appropriate level of study, with the faculty member I felt best suited for the student. After a few years, my student’s auditioned a semester early to secure a space in my studio. I additionally made hiring decisions for our associate vocal faculty, which was a treat. I think we were likely the only voice faculty in the country who actually enjoyed being together. I afforded the associate faculty complete academic freedom, and independence. I never attempted to require a percentage of my opinion as a determining factor for a student’s grade. My jury comments were just that. Comments. There are retirement options available for the teachers retirement system of Texas, or a Texas money market fund. When I started, the medical benefits were excellent; however, they deteriorated over the years. Obviously, I enjoyed much of my time there. It was a fulfilling job. I felt honored to have the opportunity. Colin afford me the freedom to pursue academic, and creative excellence.
cons: As is the norm for academia, everything depends on one’s Dean, and upper administration. When I started, I had an excellent Dean, who was impressed with my work, and supportive of my program. Unfortunately, that changed. Although there were several exceptions on the crux of the full time music faculty was mediocre, at best. They were petty and childish. That should not have been a surprise, given the typical dynamics of a music program; however, it was exhausting, and absolutely unnecessary! The problematic individuals didn’t have the ethics required amongst the sum of them to fill half of a shaker of salt. Games, evil plotting p, and the calculatedly schemes of jealousy were common place. It was a common place for them to completely sabotage, an innocent students, GPA, and dreams of a music career, just to serve their selfish, current, boring agenda. Dullards! That I found quite irritating. Total unnecessary drama. Heavens! It was always watching for the next boot to fall. (Humpty Dumpty drama!) if I have half the effort into teaching that they did into manipulation, they may have been adequate? Yet, they were not. Inbreeds from the music school in the next town. My days would be limited. Che sera!

pros: Under the current President there are no pros. It use to be a satisfying work environment where hard work received recognition. Dr. Cary Israel put Collin College in the national spot lot and practiced shared governance whenever possible.
cons: Finally had enough and resigned last year. Current President Dr. Matkin is an egotistical and arrogant person. Could care less about faculty and staff. He makes fun of people in front of an entire room and thinks it is funny. He spends more time at car dealerships than his office. He has made such a top-heavy organization with too many VP titles without hiring essential workers actually teaching students. This college is headed towards baccalaureate programs and head to 20 years backward steps with more vocational programs then academic programs. He destroyed the reputation of San Jacinto community college and is doing the same thing at Collin. Did not take Covid seriously, as a result many people have died. Any faculty expressing free speech and academic freedom. Matkin tries to say faculty not fires their contracts were just not renewed, but is unable to say why because each faculty had an impeccable evaluation every year previously. On a sidenote, you can hardly understand what he is saying when he is speaking, and whenever he is speaking is lying.

review_title: Work here if you enjoy inefficiency!
pros:
- Covered medical insurance, but all public higher education institutions do this.

- Snacks
cons:
- Training is not efficient because the trainer is a part-time advisor. It doesn't make sense for a part-timer (in office 2x weekly) to be training full-time advisors (5x week obviously). It was 2 weeks before someone told me I should be clocking in and out daily, and the person that told me was NOT my supervisor. I had to throw a literal fit to get an advising handbook.

- Leadership does not understand how to lead. The team has many suggestions for how things could be changed - like the student queue not being closed until 5pm. That doesn't make things fair for the advisors nor does it teach students accountability of going somewhere during the regular hours AND before they close! The college clearly only cares about enrollment numbers and not the advisors doing the enrollment. When these concerns and feedback are brought up by staff, they are ignored. I was told trying to get your concerns heard from anybody above our supervisors was like "beating a dead horse". 

- Messaging is trash from leadership. Chunky emails scolding employees saying "we need to be better" for missing a student that needed advising AFTER 5PM, but 20 mins later it's an email about ice cream in the breakroom since we "work so hard". Lots of micromanaging, even from the part-time advisors? So weird. Be prepared to not be trusted by the supervisors enough to even work remotely to do "College Day" which was 30 mins of videos on Youtube. We had to come onto the closed campuses for 2 hours to do that nonsense. 

Overall, I've never been in a more unorganized, discouraging environment. Higher ed professionals coming from large institutions, beware.

pros: The campus itself is a nice place. It is clean and neat. People here are nice, friendly and helpful. Many professors are dedicated to providing a quality education to their students.
cons:
If you are considering employment as an associate (part time) professor, you should know a few things. A whopping 70 percent of all professors at Collin are part time. These people teach the same amount of class hours as the full time professors, but are paid a small fraction of their salaries. Last year, I worked my full class load, and was paid just $14, 300. This year, I am on course to earn a whopping $18,000.  Part timers receive NO benefits, except for a small "retirement fund". 

Collin has no economic incentive to promote professors. Once you are hired as part time, you have virtually no chance of being promoted to a full time position.

review_title: Great employees, but they need less red tape
pros: My experience with middle management and down has been very good. They've been willing to make changes that are in the best interest of the school and the students. The benefits for full time staff are pretty good.
cons: It takes too long to have meaningful changes made. The approval process at the upper management/board level hurts the school. The upper management means well. The President is doing a great job, but it seems like it takes too long to make changes that don't come from upper management.

job_title: Associate Professor in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The students are very good, bright and eager to learn.
cons: The administration causally lies to employees.  The over-use of part-time professors is grotesque and borderline out of compliance with state regulations.  I would say 80-90% of the classes are taught my low-paid, low-energy part-timers.  Courses are often shuffled around at the last minute and the course themselves are not very well-organized.  The administration eliminated departments and chairs and I watched two-thirds of the faculty leave, myself included.

review_title: Nice Place to Work - Exception IT
pros:
For the most part people are very nice to work with and for.
More laid back environment.
If you work within the Education side, this is an excellent environment to work.
The Board, President, and VP's of the college truly have the best interest of the students, faculty and staff in mind.  Unfortunately they can't be all places at all times to see some of the things going on.
CIO and Above A+
cons:
Where to start.
Health Benefits: D-
   There is nothing the college can do about this.  The benefits are the same ones that all state employees "enjoy".  They have gone down hill.
Pay Rate: C-

IT Related Only:
  CIO and Above A+
  Some Management below CIO: F-  
  Some IT Managers treat employees most employees with the least amount of respect unless the CIO or above is present.  There is definitely an in-crowd and undying loyalty to the director level is rewarded with promotions, even if the prospect is not qualified.  These people are promoted because they often do not meet the minimum qualifications set in HR and therefore would be ineligible for consideration.  

High Turnover.

Use of old outdated technology like Novell because the in-group knows nothing else.  They should take some of the classes offered at the college and start using Active Directory so that they can do things like run a SUS server or use Group Policies to push down updates and have better management over hosts.

Should allow employees to get at least some professional development.  A lot of people start there and watch their skills stagnate to become completely obsolete.

College overall is also in the process of consolidating many positions.  This just puts the same amount of work of multiple people on, in many cases, one person.

review_title: In general it has been good
pros: Great overall environment, enjoy the job and the people in general.
cons: Direct supervisor is a very rigid fellow, and he sets up unrealistic rules. Even though he is a great resource because of his experience, it very difficult to work for him. I am actually looking for another job.

review_title: If your supervisor is former Laboratory Technician...
pros: There are many professional people out there working as part time Professors.
cons:
Unfortunately, if you want to do your job right, this is not the place to be employed. If your Associate Dean is former Lab Technician, a Board of Appeals Chair is evening administrator and some others management members are often at the level of sales associate (or worked and have been trained as sales associates) than expect the work there to be beyond disorganized and disaster because these people don't know what they are doing.
Expect harassment, discrimination, "0" tolerance if you do honest work and don't falsify grades for some students who are habitual parasites, constantly disrupt your class, don't study and have no idea what is the difference between acid and base. Grade them as your Laboratory Technician tells you or you will be in trouble.
Don't expect any help from full time faculty: I was waiting 5 hours to meet with full time faculty member when I needed his advice and the one who was supposedly assigned as my mentor received a paper from some trade school in Fort Worth that she has Ph.D but she did not earn it and when her students asked  what is the shape of sulfur hexafluoride he responded she need to look at her notes. She was never present in her office during office hours and her students complained that they don't have Professor to teach the class because this "missy" was always 5 chapters behind the schedule.
Expect to be paid for 7 hours, work 75 per week, drive to different college to get advice about anything if you are part timer and not Lab Technicians favorite.
